key_points: Judge Bruce Schroeder defended his decision allowing Kyle Rittenhouse to pick six alternate jurors from a raffle tumbler.
Kyle Rittenhouse, 18, charged with fatally shooting two men and injuring a third, drew six alternates who would not participate in deliberations.
Schroeder has allowed defendants to pick alternate jurors for nearly 20 years without complaints.
The practice is unusual; typically, a courtroom clerk would draw jurors' numbers.
Schroeder referenced a past trial in Racine, Wisconsin, to explain the practice's origin, aiming to avoid bad optics.
He believes letting the defendant make the draw makes people feel better and maintains control.
Prosecutors or defense attorneys did not oppose Schroeder's decision during the Rittenhouse trial.
Schroeder criticized those questioning the practice as attempting to undermine the trial's result.
Rittenhouse pleaded not guilty, claiming self-defense in the shootings during civil unrest in Kenosha, Wisconsin.
Schroeder also addressed his decision to bar the use of the word 'victims' to describe the men Rittenhouse shot, noting it's a standard courtroom rule.
